Comment: Because Democrats don’t have a platform, a movement, or a leader - what is there to support?  I’m an easily winnable voter for Democrats. I have always been decidedly opposed to Trump and MAGA and I don’t have any sort of ideological purity test that would prevent me from voting for candidates who don’t agree with me on everything.   Yet, it’s impossible to call myself a Democrat because I don’t know what the hell *they* even think they are; they are entirely rudderless and have been since the end of Obama.   Democrats need to stop being so afraid to piss people off and leave people out - you can’t actively include and represent everyone. Get a point of view, find the right messenger, and put it out there and quick because once Trump is gone, the anti-Trump vote is also going to be in peril.

Comment: Democrats aren’t benefitting because they aren’t doing anything coherent to meaningfully resist Trump. To a degree, they’re limited in what they can do in a Republican trifecta, but by and large, all they’ve done is whine.   Most of them are complaining and hand wringing, some are writing op-eds about “the end of Democracy” and “this isn’t the America I love.” Others are preaching to the choir in CNN or MSNBC interviews.   Some are even trying little solo act demonstrations like Senate filibusters or visiting wrongfully deported prisoners, but it doesn’t feel like doing anything. It just reeks of self-aggrandizement and trying to jockey for promotions to the Senate, governor’s mansion, 2028 presidential nomination, etc.   There’s no rallying cry for unity coming from anywhere in the party. It’s all just finger-pointing and selling themselves as “we’re the party that isn’t Donald Trump!” A stale ham sandwich also isn’t Donald Trump, so…

Comment: Dems don’t often have punchy catch phrases but for any voter who really cares, they shouldn’t need those. A good example of what Dems stand for is a story from NPR that I heard on the radio yesterday and that was posted in article form on here earlier. Trump just defunded a big national fire academy in PA or MD, I can’t remember which, that is highly regarded for the quality of firefighters it produces and that also is a huge boost to the local economy. They interviewed a Trump voter who was an instructor at the academy or something and he said he’s disappointed because the decision is impacting him financially but also could be disastrous for firefighting all across the country without recruits receiving high quality training.   This funding was never in question when Dems were writing budgets. Dems want highly trained firefighters, and they want funding for dozens or even hundreds of other institutions that Trump is eviscerating. Is funding these institutions progressive and/or sexy and does it all come with a catch phrase? No, not really. But this is really important stuff and unfortunately a lot of people may not realize that until it’s gone.

Comment: You just revealed a fundamental issue Democrats don’t even know they are facing - “the funding was never in question”.   The whole budget slashing thing is a prime example of this tension for me. People see the hatchet job that DOGE and Musk and Trump are doing and they may not agree with many decisions or the approach as a whole - but they look at Democrats and see that “they don’t even question anything”.   Democrats have been too slow on the uptake and too protective of the status quo. They project a sense of intellectual superiority that comes off as dismissive of the real concerns and questions that voters have.   Voters who may have serious doubts about DOGE cuts feel even less comforted by Democrats who flatly dismiss any reason to question whether budgets should ever be cut at all. You may disagree with Trump’s solutions, but you feel like you’re not even allowed to ask the question to Democrats; or worse, will be laughed at or mocked for even thinking about it.  Funding specialized firefighter training classes isn’t a platform. Cutting government spending is. Again, this isn’t a specific decision I agree with, but Democrats focusing on criticizing this decision falls flat with me because they don’t have any point of view about budgets and spending as a whole.  It isn’t unique to this issue - across many domains (the border is a great example), voters feel like Trump has imperfect or even stupid solutions, but they feel like Democrats aren’t even engaging with the questions and concerns that are out there. They tell you “everything is fine, Trump is bad, and you’re stupid for thinking that there is anything wrong with budgets or the border”.   It’s not a winning message and it’s not a platform, unless their platform is “the status quo”.

And oh yeah if you struggle with infertility, best of luck.  Adopting costs 10's of thousands of dollars and so does IVF.    You work you can have a home. Comment: I agree that at the end of the day, the party needs to appeal to the electorate and it needs to figure out how to play to the lowest common denominator. The person I was replying to, by virtue of being on a political forum, is probably not a tuned out ignorant voter so I’m a bit more confused as to why that kind of person is saying the Dems don’t stand for anything. Unless he was speaking about how voters don’t perceive them to stand for anything instead of himself perceiving that.   I don’t think they’re perfect, but to me Dems stand for good relationships with allies, mostly beneficial free trade policies, mostly competent administration of key institutions that help Americans and the country in general, steady expansion of social safety net programs etc. Doesn’t make a ton of sense to me for left leaning voters and reliable Dem voters to be feeling super burned out and like the party isn’t doing anything. In comparison to Trump and even other Republicans, with Dems the country is at least treading water and not backsliding toward a conservative engineered collapse.
Author: StormOk7544

Comment: I would agree that Dems are losing the messaging war. Badly. They are going to have to come up with slogans and a way to validate some of voters’ concerns. The border and immigration are issues that I feel voters are most justified in being upset with Dems about. Immigration doesn’t bother me personally, but even moderate Dems were answering polls saying it mattered to them and doing very little to stop the flow into the country through the border simply doesn’t make a ton of sense.   With most other issues, I’m frankly baffled as to the positions voters take on them. Tariffs, who on earth thinks that’s a good idea? Defunding everything and anything even though these institutions do a ton of good for Americans and have kept us as the global superpower and shotcaller on the world stage since WW2. Why does frustration with Dems for not caring a ton about deficit spending justify cutting training for firefighters, programs that help pay rent for older veterans, over the phone assistance with social security benefits etc? Not only does cutting these programs harm all of the beneficiaries, who are just average American people trying to get by, but it also doesn’t even remotely tackle the deficit and debt. Probably have to hike taxes and make changes to Medicare and Medicaid to really make an impact on federal spending.   So yeah, Dems are losing the messaging war and that’s not good and needs to change, but a big chunk of their platform -supporting productive, helpful institutions - is a decent platform and should be enough to defeat Trump. Another frustrating thing is that voters say they’re crying out for big change, but it’s a Herculean task to get them and Republicans to support things like minimum wage increases, workers’ rights like union support, and movement toward universal healthcare. Voters want change but they can’t decide what sort of change they actually want and instead have consciously chosen Trump, the guy who is the clear greater evil and is obviously only going to make virtually every issue many voters care about far worse.
Author: StormOk7544
